bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lewis J. Moorman, March 18, 1946

div1.p: Hench has read Moorman's paper on the yellow fever experiments and agrees that they did not have Congressional support. However, Hench questions Moorman whether it is fair to imply that Congress interfered with the scientists' work when they were never asked to do one thing or another.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lewis J. Moorman, March 18, 1946
div1.opener:
March 18, 1946
Dr. Lewis J. Moorman
304 Osler Building
1200 North Walker
Oklahoma City, Oklahoma
My dear Dr. Moorman:
div1.p:
I have read over your paper with great interest and it is
a new slant on the yellow fever episode. Nevertheless, I think you
are right in that they did not have any Congressional support. How-
ever, from their standpoint, they didn't need any and I doubt if they
asked for it. The yellow fever experiments were set up as a special
project by the Surgeon General and Reed. Means were made available
by the Army, almost exclusively by the medical department of the Army,
and they didn't even want to become very much involved with the other
branches of the Army, as their experiments were something in the
nature of a secret. When they needed financial help, they went to
General Wood. When they needed the help of the local authorities,
particularly the Spanish CouncilConsul, they went to him to get his per-
mission to carry out experiments on immigrant Spaniards, newly arrived
in Cuba.

The only time Congress became involved was leter when
suggestions were made to pension the parties concerned, particularly
in the cases of the widows of Drs. Reed and Lazear, and you will remember
that Congress dilly--dallyed for years.

In summary, you are right in saying that the experiments
were done without Congressional control, but is it fair to imply that
Congress interfered with their work when they never were asked to do
one thing or another?

I shall appreciate it greatly if you would send me a copy of
your paper for my files, either before or after it is published. Where
were you planning to publish it?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
